Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER: The Molecular Interactome of Synaptogenesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary objective of this EAGER project is to provide infrastructure that will have broad scientific and social impacts. The scientific information and reagents generated in this project will impact a wide range of scientific activities relevant to the NSF BRAIN Initiative. The protein interactions uncovered will provide the basis for hypothesis-driven research neurobiology programs in humans and model organisms. Discovery of the ensemble of molecular interactions of the synaptic cleft, and sharing these data and reagents with the scientific community, will provide stepping stones for many other projects, increasing the overall rate of discovery in neuroscience, developmental and structural biology, proteomics, and related fields. The PIs have a strong commitment to undergraduate teaching in their laboratories, and have extensive experience training undergraduate and minority students in research projects. Several aspects of the proposed BRAIN EAGER project, and the anticipated follow-up structural and functional studies of synaptic proteins, are ideally suited for such undergraduate projects. The interdisciplinary nature of our EAGER proposal, at the interface of neurobiology, cell biology, systems biology, bioengineering, bioinformatics, and molecular biophysics, will allow the PIs to expand their undergraduate research programs, and to proactively recruit undergraduate minority students into these programs, training the next generation of molecular neuroscientists.

It is estimated that the human brain is composed of about 120 billion neurons, connected through more than 100 trillion synapses. Despite the astronomical number of possible connections, during development the brain is wired with exquisite precision so that brain circuits precisely integrate and process sensory inputs to generate proper motor outputs as well as behavior and social interactions. At the cellular and molecular level, each individual synapse requires the apposition of structurally and functionally matching pre- and post-synaptic protein pairs. Although there are trillions of synapses, each synapse is likely to be unique. Synaptic specificity is thought to arise from a code of specific interactions among adhesive molecules acting across the synaptic cleft. However, if a synaptic code does indeed exist, it is not known how it works, which synaptic molecules are involved, how they connect to each other, or their structures. The PIs will develop a high-throughput (HTP) program aimed at building an experimentally-validate protein interaction network of synaptic proteins and exodomains. The protein interactions and functions discovered in this project will provide a more comprehensive and unified view of the synaptic protein interaction network, which will enable the scientific community to determine whether a synaptic code may exist. New molecular pathways will be uncovered. These efforts to characterize the synaptic protein interaction network will provide innovative insights into brain circuit formation, and likely result in totally unexpected discoveries. These results will broadly inform cellular and molecular neurobiology and open the door to many interdisciplinary follow up studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is estimated that the human brain is composed of ~120 billion neurons, connected through >100 trillion synapses. Despite the astronomical number of possible connections, during development the brain is wired with exquisite precision so that brain circuits precisely integrate and process sensory inputs to generate proper motor outputs, as well as behavior and social interactions. At the cellular and molecular level, each individual synapse requires the apposition of structurally and functionally matching pre- and post-synaptic protein pairs. Synaptic specificity is thought to arise from a "code" of specific interactions among adhesive molecules acting across the synaptic cleft (Fig. 1). However, if a synaptic "code" does indeed exist, little is known on how it works, which synaptic molecules are involved, how they connect to each other, or their structures.

Intellectual Merit.  We have developed a medium-throughput screen for protein-protein interactions, and applied this for discovery of new protein-protein interactions among human brain proteins associated with neuronal synapses. Using bioinformatics methods and our own biological knowledge, we have compiled list of secreted (or ectodomain) synaptic proteins. Expression constructs for 258 genes coding for synaptic proteins (or their domains) were designed (Fig. 2) and cloned into high-level eukaryotic expression vectors, and each protein produced in HEK293 cells with two different affinity tags (Fig. 3). These reagents allowed us to carry out more than 11,000 binary interaction experiments using an ELISA-based protein-protein interaction screen in microtiter plates (Fig. 4). Approximately 20 control interactions were validated, and 73 new interactions were identified. Several of these new interactions have been validated with biophysical measurements, by purifying the two interacting proteins, and measuring their binding affinity using BioLayer Interferometry (BLI) and isothermal titration calorimetry. A novel high-throughput assay for synapse formation was also developed, and ~13% of the proteins tested were found to have significant synapse formation activity.

Although this two-year BRAIN EAGER award has only allowed us to scratch the surface of the synaptic proteome, the new protein-protein interactions we have already discovered in this project will provide a more comprehensive and unified view of the synaptic protein interaction network. This work demonstrates the value of our approach for novel discovery, and supports our plans for larger-scale studies of protein interactions among additional synaptic protein pairs. As our initial research program expands, it will uncover new molecular pathways, and enable the scientific community to determine whether a synaptic "code" may exist, and its governing rules. Our efforts to characterize the synaptic protein interaction network have already resulted in totally unexpected protein interactions, and will provide innovative insights into brain circuit formation. These results will broadly inform cellular and molecular neurobiology, and open the door to many interdisciplinary follow up studies.

Broader Impacts: The scientific information and reagents generated in this project can impact a wide range of scientific activities relevant to the NSF BRIAN Initiative. The protein interactions uncovered have already begun to provide the basis for hypothesis-driven research programs in our laboratories, including follow up structural and functional studies. Discovery of the ensemble of molecular interactions of the synaptic cleft, and sharing these data and reagents with the scientific community, will provide stepping stones for many other projects, increasing the overall rate of discovery in neuroscience, developmental and structural biology, proteomics, and related fields. These same methods can also be applied to study other extracellular eukarotic protein interaction networks.  

Extensive novel reagents were generated and many novel protein-protein interactions were discovered. The synthetic genes and HEK293 expression vectors for 258 human synaptic proteins developed in this project are available to the broad scientific community for biochemical studies and antibody production.  Expression data and protocols are also available in our laboratory information management system.

The interdisciplinary nature of our BRAIN-EAGER project, at the interface of neurobiology, cell biology, systems biology, bioengineering, bioinformatics, and molecular biophysics, has provided the opportunity for diverse undergraduate and postdoctoral research training activities at Rutgers University.  Research training was provided to one female postdoc (Sinem Ozgul), four undergraduates (Ian Hagee, Hersh Doshi, Christopher Kim, and Sumie Kakehi), two female scientists (Dr. Cuifeng Yin, Dr. Natalia Denissova), and an international MS student (Davide Sereni, Italy). All personnel, including the undergraduate students, have been trained in the wide spectrum of techniques used during this project, including preliminary bioinformatics analysis, protein expression in HEK293 cells, high-throughput protein-protein interaction screening, and rigorous biophysical characterization of protein complex formation. These technologies are important for the scientific growth not only of these undergraduate students and postdoctoral associate, but of the other scientific staff as well.
